awd_titl_txt: Manufacturing USA/GOALI: Visualizing Nanoscale Evolution during Aluminum Alloy Melt Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Reducing the weight of vehicles that move people and goods on land, sea and air is critical for improving fuel economy and increasing mission payload.  Aluminum alloys are used in the automotive and aerospace industries to meet this need because of their high strength-to-weight ratio. For improved fuel efficiency, however, higher strength and lighter weight alloys are needed, and this can be achieved though the incorporation of nanosized particles in the aluminum matrix. A novel approach to producing the nanoparticles has been developed based on the introduction of gas bubbles directly into the molten aluminum.  Blowing nitrogen gas into the melt can produce aluminum nitride particles that are 50 nanometers in size. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research to provide the knowledge needed to control the particle size and shape which lead to optimized mechanical properties and performance.  The results from this research will enable industry to scale up this process from small laboratory melts to commercial size ingots, which will enable the development of lightweight alloys for ground, air, and sea transportation, with direct benefit to the U.S. economy.  The students involved in this research will have the opportunity to interact with the engineers from industry who are part of the team.  An integrated experimental and modeling approach will be utilized, which is forming the new basis for materials engineering education.  Outreach activities emphasize the mentoring of women and underrepresented minorities.
 
The incorporation of 50-200 nanometer particles has been shown to improve the strength and high temperature stability of aluminum alloys.  However, due to agglomeration of the nanoparticles and insufficient bonding at the nanoparticle-matrix interface, the mechanical properties of the composite material are often degraded. A new approach, in which the reinforcing nanoparticles are generated directly in the molten metal via an in-situ gas-liquid reaction has been shown to produce nanosized, dispersed AlN and TiC particles.  In this project, the nano- to micro- structural dynamics governing the process will be investigated. Insights from these fundamental studies will guide the identification of a process condition window for large-scale in-situ aluminum nanocomposite manufacturing, which produces a nanoparticle morphology and distribution with optimum mechanical properties.  To examine the nanometer-scale thermodynamic and kinetic processes, in-situ reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED) will be utilized during alloy nitridation in a molecular-beam epitaxy (MBE) system. For in-situ 3D nanoparticle visualization, a mini-melter will be developed and 3D visualization of the nanocomposites will be achieved using synchrotron-based X-ray nanotomography.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Aluminum alloys are used extensively in aerospace and automotive applications due to their high strength to weight ratio. To further improve their strength and high temperature stability, particles are added to the molten alloy to create a metal-matrix composite. It has been established that reducing the size of the reinforcing particles to nanoscale can dramatically improve the properties.  However, today?s commercial melt processes result in agglomeration of the nanoparticles and insufficient bonding at the nanoparticle-matrix interface, resulting in the mechanical properties of the composite material being degraded. Several new approaches had been reported in which the reinforcing nanoparticles are generated directly in the molten metal.  In this project, the underlying mechanisms controlling the nano-particle formation were investigated. The results from our fundamental studies will enable the identification of a process condition window for large-scale in situ aluminum nanocomposite manufacturing which produces a nanoparticle morphology and distribution with optimum mechanical properties.  The outcomes of this project reflect the research performed at the University of Michigan, Eck Industries, NADCA; including experiments conducted at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Lab, and the National Synchrotron Light Source II at Brookhaven National Lab.

Intellectual Merit

The program addressed the following questions: How do the processing parameters, e.g. aluminum alloy and reinforcing particle composition and reaction temperature influence the thermodynamics and kinetics of the reaction? How do other phases influence the nanoparticle formation and dispersion in the melt during processing? A multiscale integrated computational- experimental approach was used.  3D visualization of the nanocomposites was achieved using synchrotron-based X-ray nano-tomography. The sizes, shapes, and 3D distributions of nanoparticles in the casting were quantified. In parallel, post-mortem microstructural characterizations and chemical analyses were performed using scanning electron microscopy and energy-dispersive spectroscopy. We found that there are several routes for nanoparticle TiC and SiC formation, depending on the process conditions. Using those insights, larger scale castings were produced with improved mechanical properties. Thus, this project provides further understanding of the nanoparticle formation process to promote its engineering application for manufacturing large-scale aluminum nanocomposites.

Broader Impacts

Higher strength aluminum alloy castings are a key element of the industry roadmap to achieve vehicles with reduced weight, enabling higher fuel economy and longer range electric vehicles. While melt processing of metallic alloys is already a multi-billion dollar industry, deeper technical expertise in thermodynamics, kinetics and solidification ICME modeling is needed.  This project added knowledge to all of these key areas of materials science. By gaining a more complete understanding of the effects of process conditions on nano-particle formation, there is greater potential for scaling up of the melt process. The progress made in improving in situ processing of aluminum castings has attracted interest beyond our Goali partners, Eck Industries and NADCA, with General Motors providing mechanical testing of our samples.  In addition, NADCA is assisting in disseminating our results to the broader melt processing industry. Note that insights gained by this work can also be extended to other alloys including magnesium and copper castings.

Direct educational benefits of this project included the training of undergraduate and graduate students in casting equipment design and process operation, state-of-the-art synchrotron-based imaging, and various microstructure analysis techniques. The students benefitted from the multiscale nature of this research, the exposure to advanced research facilities, and the collaborations with industry partners.


Last Modified: 09/23/2021
Modified by: Alan Taub

Images (1 of )
  • Al-TiC composite made via self-propagating high-temperature synthesis: (a) Microstructure showing TiC and Al3Ti in an Al matrix. (b) Representative reconstructed slice of a tomography micropillar (c) Cubic volume rendering of elongated Al3Ti and TiC within Al created from stacking tomography data.
    Reese C, Gladstein A, Fedors J, De Andrade V, Mishra B, Shahani A, Taub A. In situ Al-TiC composites fabricated by self-propagating high-temperature reaction: insights on reaction pathways and their microstructural signatures. Metall. Mater. Trans. A. 2020
    Copyrighted
    Alan Taub
    In-situ composite made via self-propagating high-temperature synthesis
  • Al-TiC MMC made via salt-flux reaction synthesis: (a) Microstructural overview. (b) Higher magnification of (a) showing hexagonal TiC particles, inset shows chemistry at the red dot. (c) Cylindrical volume rendering of reconstructed tomography data showing hexagonal TiC platelets in the Al matrix.
    Reese C, Gladstein A, Fedors J, De Andrade V, Mishra B, Shahani A, Taub A. In situ Al-TiC composites fabricated by self-propagating high-temperature reaction: insights on reaction pathways and their microstructural signatures. Metall. Mater. Trans. A. 2020
    Copyrighted
    Alan Taub
    Schematic depicting formation mechanisms of TiC via thermite-assisted self-propagating high-temperature reactions
  • Microstructure of an Al-SiC MMC made via metal-based polymer-pyrolysis (MBPP). (a) Micrograph showing ovular structures from the polymer decomposition. (b) magnified view of one of the structures showing SiC as both polygons and needles, the inset showing chemical analysis from multiple points.
    A. Gladstein, C. Reese, A. Taub, Comparison of In-Situ Aluminum Metal Matrix Composite Processes - MS&T 2019
    Copyrighted
    Alan Taub
    Microstructure of an Al-SiC MMC made via metal-based polymer-pyrolysis (MBPP)
